clinical_study.brief_title: Recovery of Cardiovascular Function With Epidural Stimulation After Human Spinal Cord Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Recovery of Cardiovascular Function With Epidural Stimulation After Human Spinal Cord Injury

brief_summary.textblock: We propose to demonstrate that epidural stimulation (ES) can be used to recover significant levels of autonomic control of cardiovascular and respiratory function as well as the ability to voluntarily control leg movements below the injury level. This intervention would provide an immediate therapeutic alternative to individuals who now have no recourse for treatment.

detailed_description.textblock: We will enroll 4 research participants who have sustained a motor complete SCI to participate in the proposed experiments. Participants will be screened for eligibility, followed by 80 days of usual care, epidural implantation, 80 days of cardiovascular epidural stimulation training, 80 days of voluntary movement (VM) epidural stimulation training and finally 80 days of stand epidural stimulation training. These interventions are done in sequential order, however they are cumulative. In between each intervention, participants will undergo motor and cardiovascular experiments and assessments.

primary_outcome.measure: Recovery of Autonomic control of Cardiovascular function

secondary_outcome.measure: Recovery of Autonomic control of respiratory function

arm_group.description: 80 sessions each of epidural spinal cord stimulation for 1) cardiovascular function; 2) voluntary movement; and 3) standing.
